$NodeNews:17.body.value:
During Texas Camp 2017, we hosted a public planning session, more like a town hall really, which included the 2017 planning team and camp attendees. After the camp, we issued a digital survey to camp-goers to get broader input from those who weren’t able to attend that session. Based on the input from these initiatives, and 2017 attendee demographics, we made a few big changes to the camp!

Austin, Texas 

We’ve opted to keep Texas Camp in Austin. Keeping the camp in the same city year after year will allow the planning team to focus on iteratively improving the camp year after year. This year, based on feedback from attendees and the planning team, we’ve moved the venue location a bit more central. For 2018 we’ll be at the Norris Event Center, which is a bit more centrally located for lodging, dining, and after-party options.  

Save the dates - May 31-June 2

The first feedback-based change we’ll be implementing is shifting the camp dates. We’ll stick scheduling the event seven weeks after DrupalCon, but we’ll be moving from Friday, Saturday, Sunday to Thursday, Friday, and Saturday. This will allow our attendees to travel home on Sunday and recoup for the week ahead without disrupting session turnout. It was a bummer for our Sunday speakers who presented to smaller audiences than our Saturday speakers and a bummer for folks who missed out on half the sessions due to flights and long drives. We’d also like to let folks get back to their families without feeling rushed to leave the event.

Looking forward

The planning for 2018 has already begun, but it’s not too late to join! We’re looking for folks to help with outreach, signal boosting and to help with session selection in April.

We'd love to hear from people in San Antonio, Dallas, Houston, and Austin to make sure the major markets in the state are included in the planning and promotion.

Our goal in 2017 was to make an event which Texas Drupalers would be proud of and we think we’ve achieved that goal and then some. Attendee feedback was overwhelmingly positive. Together with the planning team, we’re committed to delivering again in 2018.

You can help make this event a reality 

We're looking for generous sponsors to help fund this event. Download the prospectus and contact us to secure your sponsorship today. 

Download the Prospectus

$NodeNews:18.body.value:
Texas Camp 2017 was a rip-roaring success! Here's a quick recap as well as some resources from the event.

Attendee Demographics

Where we’re from

  • 76% Texas (43% from Austin alone!)
  • 16 states
  • 3 countries (USA, Canada, Nicaragua)

What we do

  • 62% Developer/Technical
  • 12% C-Suite/Owner
  • 12% Marketing/Client Services
  • 8% Marketing/Sales
  • 4% Design/UX
  • 2% Other

Where we work

  • 49% Agency
  • 18% Non-Agency/Internal
  • 13% Education
  • 11% Hosting
  • 9% Government

Session Videos

Many thanks to our many wonderful speakers who presented at our camp last year. You can view all of our 2017 sessions on our Texas Camp YouTube channel.

Shout out to our 2017 sponsors

Thank you to all our sponsors for helping make 2017 happen! We couldn’t have done it without you: Rackspace, Amazee Labs, Four Kitchens, Pantheon, Promet Source, LevelTen Interactive, Kanopi Studios, TexasCreative, Softescu, Acquia, amazee.io, Zilleem, and Bluespark.

NodeNews:20.title: Tickets and Sessions and Sponsorship, Oh My! The Texas Camp site is LIVE

$NodeNews:20.body.value:
It's the trifecta! Texas Camp is live and with it, all the things you've been waiting for. 

Submit your Session idea 

We're looking for a few good folks to present at Texas Camp. Need inspiration? Check out the illustrious lineup of speakers who graced our halls in 2017. 

Submit a Session

Buy your ticket

Tickets are on sale now for the low-low price of $25 -- limited to the first 50 people to register for this event. After that, tickets increase to $50, which is still a great value for two days of Drupal goodness! 

Get your ticket

Sponsor Texas Camp

This event wouldn't be possible without the generous support from sponsors like you. Check out our different sponsor packages to find the perfect fit for your company.

View the Prospectus

$NodeNews:54.body.value:
Want to get some public speaking experience deep in the heart of Texas? The Texas Camp crew is looking for Drupalistas and digital wranglers to come speak at the event. Session submission is currently open and will close on Thursday, April 19.

You can see what’s already been submitted here. Not sure how you can contribute to the lineup? We’re looking for mighty fine content in the following areas:

  • Backend Development
  • Frontend Development
  • Content Management
  • Content Strategy
  • User Experience
  • Building Community
  • DevOps
  • Site Building
  • Project Management
  • Business Development
  • Other

GET TO SUBMITTIN’, Y’ALL

Want to improve your chances of getting selected? Here’s how the process works:

We’ll scrub all personally identifiable information from the sessions so that the selection team is unbiased. A volunteer who isn’t on the selection committee will remove all names, gender pronouns, company names, and so on to give everyone a fair chance.

Each session will be reviewed, evaluated, and given numerical ratings based on each of the following categories:

  • Relevance of the session topic
  • Session description and demonstration of subject mastery
  • Speaker experience, (don’t worry, we won’t penalize you if you’re new to presenting)
  • Experience level
  • Number of submissions the anonymous person already submitted - we try to only have one session per speaker, though we do occasionally break this rule

After each session has been rated by each person on the committee, a spreadsheet will calculate the average of each session’s reviews. We’ll select camp’s sessions from those, both by ranking and also by topic -- we want to make sure we have a good mix of topics for attendees.

Pro tip: Want to increase your chances of getting selected? We get so few advanced sessions that the odds are greater your session will be selected if it contains advanced material.

Ain’t sure speaking is right for you? There are other ways to get involved. Follow our Facebook group for the latest news, and let us know you’ll be at the event. You can also sign up for the Austin Drupal User Group Slack to join the chatter, or join one of the Texas Drupal User Groups to get involved in your own community. We’ve got groups for Austin, Houston, San Antonio, and Dallas.

See y’all in Austin this May!

NodeNews:60.title: Join us for training at Texas Camp

$NodeNews:60.body.value:
Want to learn to do it better with Drupal? Come on down to Texas Camp on Thursday, May 31, to join us for one of our excellent training opportunities. Training ain’t included in the price of general admission to Texas Camp, but for $25, you can enjoy a full-day of learning from one of our expert trainers.

The training opportunities we have lined up are:

  • Drupal 8 Certification Crash Course
  • Actionable Strategies to Improve Visitor Experience
  • Visual Regression Testing with BackstopJS

This is a great opportunity for you or members of your team to get hands-on experience with new material. Make sure you purchase your ticket soon; training usually sells out well in advance of the camp.

If you’ve got a great idea that you think other Texas Drupalers would want to learn about, let us know. We’re open to adding more training options if we hear from y’all soon.

NodeNews:78.title: Nikki Stevens is Keynoting Texas Camp

$NodeNews:78.body.value:
We’re pleased to announce that Nikki Stevens will keynote Texas Camp this June!

Nikki is a recipient of the 2017 Aaron Winborn award, an award which "is presented annually to an individual who demonstrates personal integrity, kindness, and above-and-beyond commitment to the Drupal community.” She is currently a Senior Technical Architect at Kanopi Studios, has been contributing to Drupal for nearly a decade, and in the past few years has been dedicated to driving a more inclusive culture within the community.

Nikki’s keynote will take place at 9AM on Friday morning, and will discuss using diversity data to inform technology. Her keynote will share knowledge she has gained in her work on Open Demographics, a platform that standardizes inclusive data demographic collection across open source communities. Nikki’s keynote will also be informed by her academic studies at Arizona State University, where she is currently pursuing a Ph.D. in data and software engineering ethics.

This is a great keynote for any organization interested in learning how to better serve a more diverse user base with technology. Make sure you don’t miss it!

Register today

NodeNews:79.title: Session submissions close in just a few days

$NodeNews:79.body.value:
Hey, y'all!

Got something worth hollerin' about? Session submissions end this week, so make sure you let us know all about your bright ideas before the call for papers closes.

Presenting at TexasCamp is a low-pressure way to get public speaking experience and share information on a topic you know and love. And since diversity is a big and important initiative in the Drupal world right now, we're itchin' to make TexasCamp a platform for new, unheard, and thoughtful voices. We've got slots and availability for talks beyond pure Drupal, so if you have some real-world insight or an out-of-the box idea for a session, send us your pitch!

Want to talk about Drupal, but not sure where to start? Consider sending a session on:

  • Drupal 8 theming
  • Module building
  • Accessibility
  • APIs
  • Composer

... or whatever you want!

We've got a great selection of proposals across a variety of topics already and are looking to increase our count. The more sessions we can choose from, the better Texas Camp will be, so don't be shy. Let us know you're an expert and submit the kind of session that you'd like to see! 

And remember: session submission closes Thursday at 11:59 PM Texas time. 

Send us your talks before it's too late!

Send 'em in

NodeNews:111.title: Saturday mornings are for tacos and keynotes!

$NodeNews:111.body.value:
Coming to Texas Camp? Make sure you arrive early on Saturday morning to catch the keynote!

Michael Schmid, the CEO of Amazee Labs, will share his insights and vision for the future of Drupal, and it’s a talk you won’t want to miss.

Many of you may know Michael, who has spent the past seven years helping grow Amazee Labs from a small agency to one with offices in Europe, South Africa, and Austin. Michael will show us what the Future of Drupal will bring, which technologies are on the horizon, how they will change the software, and why our future is looking so bright.

Get excited for Michael’s keynote! Make sure you get your tickets soon to take advantage of regular pricing. Texas Camp is going to have loads of great sessions, as well as a day of amazing training and two fantastic keynotes.

Check back next week when we announce the final schedule!

$NodeNews:138.body.value:
It's finally here! Texas Camp kicks off tomorrow bright and early with Training and Sprints at the Norris Conference Center. 

We've sold out two of our three trainings, but there's still a few seats left in Pantheon's training, Visual Regression Testing with BackstopJS. Training is just $25 and includes lunch and a PM coffee break. 

Sprints are open to anyone who wants to contribute to Drupal. You can contribute code, project management, testing, and documentation. Our keynote Nikki Stevens will be mentoring folks new to sprinting. 

Registration opens at 8AM and will go until 4PM when trainings and sprints end for the day. You're welcome to swing by even if you're not attending Training or Sprints to collect your t-shirt and badge and skip the Friday line.

$NodeNews:140.body.value:
We did it! Over six months of weekly planning meetings and so many sessions later, we've found ourselves at the end of another amazing event.

Texas Camp was a super busy week. Here's a quick run down of the events an activities that kept us occupied. 

Thursday 

  • 46 people attended the Speaker, Sponsor, and Volunteer dinner at Stiles Switch
  • 51 people received training sponsored by FFW, Pantheon, and Amazee Labs 
  • 9 people attended Sprints, which Nikki Stevens helped spearhead 

Friday

  • 170 people attended Nikki's kick-ass keynote. If you haven't watched it yet, here's your chance. 
  • Quite a few folks (but not everyone!) took part in our Group Photo 
  • 47 people attended Boardgames and Brews at 4th Tap after sessions ended 

Saturday 

  • 102 people attended Michael's keynote 
  • 36 people stuck it out and made it to the closing party at the Local Post Pub  

Inclusivity Initiatives 

This year at Texas Camp, the planning team made efforts to reach out to diverse audiences through the Drupal Diversity & Inclusion group, to participate as speakers. While we didn't hit our goal of 50%, we did come close! Of our 42 speakers, 12 (or 28%) identify as women. We're darn proud of this ratio, but know there's room for improvement for next year.

We were also able to provide vegan and gluten free meals and snack options for folks attending - even at our BBQ location! - giving everyone a seat at the table. 

Now, for some stats.

  • Final Texas Camp headcount, including trainers, camp and training attendees: 191 
  • Total sponsor dollars raised: $16,050 

 

Finally, a well-deserved shout-out to the fine folks who made this event one for the books:

Sponsors

Amazee Labs - Pantheon - FFW - Big Tuna Creative - Achieve Internet - ThinkDrop - DDEV - REDFIN - Kanopi Studios - Zilleem - Softescu - amazee.io - Last Call Media - Four Kitchens - HID 

Speakers

Nikki Stevens, Michael Schmid, Brian Perry, Dustin Younse, Abby Kingman, Ryan Bateman, Sean Dietrich, Kelly Albrecht, Cecy Correa, Darren Petersen, Jon Pugh, Joe Hyde, Ana Laura Coto Tristan, David Stinemetze, Josh Fabean, Dwayne McDaniel, Tyler Ward, Tearyne Glover, Fito Kahn, Paul Grotevant, Charles Leverington, Carlos Ospina, David Needham, Sean Eddings, Allan Chappell, Susan LaRonde, Tyler Fahey, Kristen Mayer, Kris Vanderwater, Leigh Anderson, Mike Minecki, Patrick Coffey, Mike Minecki, Trasi Judd, Chris Wright, Michael Marsello, Leopoldo Reynaga  

Volunteers

Stephanie El-Hajj, Andrew McClintock, Brandon Williams, Kristy Moon, Caryn Eaton, Charles Leverington, Leigh Anderson, Rachel Whitton, Carlos Ospina, David Needham, Yes Moon, Kevin Thull

Keep it Going

  • Take the 2018 Survey 
  • Watch the 2018 Texas Camp video playlist
  • Take a tour down Texas Camp memory lane. All photography courtesy Yes Moon. 

So many folks trekked to Austin to take part in this event, we can't help but feel a little humbled. Texas Camp was a blast to plan and a blast to run. Thanks for coming down, y'all.

$NodeNews:142.body.value: We had such a great time, we're doing it again! Join us for another edition of Texas Camp on October 18-19, 2019 in San Antonio, Texas at Codeup.  Tickets are available now and we're collecting session ideas. See all the details at https://2019.texascamp.org and join our newsletter.
